author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- Name does not meet all of the following: starts with an upper-case letter, ASCII alphanumerics only, not all letters are upper-case.
- Name is not at least 5 characters long
- Package name similar to 11 existing packages.
  <details>
  <summary>Similar package names</summary>

  1. Similar to QMDP. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 1 is at or below cutoff of 2. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 1 between lowercased names is at or below cutoff of 1.
  2. Similar to LMDB. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  3. Similar to SDDP. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  4. Similar to CSDP. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  5. Similar to UMAP. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  6. Similar to RDDP. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  7. Similar to DSDP. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  8. Similar to AMD. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  9. Similar to SIMD. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  10. Similar to MD5. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  11. Similar to MIDI. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.

  </details>


Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simple retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. Then, send a message to the `#pkg-registration` channel in the [Julia Slack](https://julialang.org/slack/) to ask for help. Include a link to this pull request.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

The naming follows from the standard abbreviation in literature on Interval Markov Decision Processes, which are Markov decision processes where the transition probability is only known within an interval.

I think this is unlikely to be accepted - a quick google doesn't yield any results related to Markov processes for me, so this isn't an especially widely known acronym it appears. 

I would suggest a more descriptive name - `IntervalMDPs` maybe, or even just `IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses`. Keep in mind that (a) package names autocomplete in the Pkg REPL (so `IntervalMar<tab>` would expand to the full name and (b) you can always do `import IntervalMDPs as IMPD` if that's desired on the user end.

Thanks for the feedback @nilshg. I see your point and do take that into consideration. But I would really prefer to keep the name if at all possible for two reasons: (a) for people working with IMDPs, we rarely ever say the full name, but rather the abbreviation and (b) I have a `cu` function that I deliberately don't export as it clashes with CUDA.jl (and I want to keep that function name as they do almost the same thing). Thus, either the user would need to write `IntervalMDP.cu`, which I find needlessly verbose, or write both `using IntervalMDP` and `import IntervalMDP as IMDP` to keep `IMDP.cu`, which may confuse a new user of the library.

While for people _in_ the field that might be a common name, people discovering it might struggle. I agree with Nils and would even favour `IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses` â€“ it is much more readable and we have editors with autocomplete these days. If an expert wants the abbreviation, they can still use the `as` syntax.
(still a [nobreak] comment if the above points are clarified)

It is not possible to use an `as` syntax for `using`. If that was possible, I would be happy with the longer `IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses`. However, I wouldn't impose on the users either to frequently write `IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses.cu` or to need both a `using` and an `import` to use the library. The shorter `IntervalMDP` I can accept if necessary, but I would still prefer `IMDP`.

> It is not possible to use an `as` syntax for `using`.

What do you mean?

```julia
julia> using Statistics: Statistics as Stat
```

works just fine, and presumably so would

```julia
julia> using IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses: IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses as IMDP
```

> ```julia
> julia> using IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses: IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses as IMDP
> ```

Huh, I have never seen this. Interesting! Thanks for showing me this. Not a nice syntax though IMO - it looks as if you are using a type named `IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses` within the `IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses` module. I would personally prefer a syntax like 
```julia
julia> using IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses as IMDP
```

But I digress. Considering the sentiment of this discussion, I will change the name of the package to `IntervalMDP`.

> I will change the name of the package to IntervalMDP

Sounds good to me!

> Huh, I have never seen this. Interesting! 

I would point to the manual section on [Standalone `using` and `import`](https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/modules/#Standalone-using-and-import):

> Possibly the most common way of loading a module is `using ModuleName`. This [loads](https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/code-loading/#code-loading) the code associated with `ModuleName`, and brings
>
> 1. **the module name**
> 2. and the elements of the export list into the surrounding global namespace.

(emphasis mine)

So the module name can be renamed just like any element of the export list.

Although I actually agree with you that `using IntervalMarkovDecisionProcesses as IMDP` would have been much nicer, and IMO Julia's `using`/`import` was a bit of a blunder, failing to learn the lessons of Python (don't do "star imports"). But now *I* digress ;-)
Since the most recent linked PR indicates this package is now registered under a new name, I think this PR can be closed?

body:
- Registering package: IMDP
- Repository: https://github.com/Zinoex/IMDP.jl
- Created by: @Zinoex
- Version: v0.1.0
- Commit: ab54eaf6fdbdaa3db0d6bc0b7187bb631d8aff6e
- Reviewed by: @Zinoex
- Reference: https://github.com/Zinoex/IMDP.jl/commit/ab54eaf6fdbdaa3db0d6bc0b7187bb631d8aff6e#commitcomment-136319947
- Description: GPU-accelerated value iteration for Interval Markov Decision Processes

title: New package: IMDP v0.1.0
